explanation:
To find the reciprocal of \( -\frac{1}{3} \), multiply by the inverse:  
\[
-\frac{1}{3} \times -3 = 1 \quad \Rightarrow \quad \text{Reciprocal} = -3
\]  
The student calculated:  
\[
\text{Reciprocal of } \frac{1}{3} = 3 \quad \text{then wrote } \frac{1}{3}  
\]  
The error occurred when the student treated \( -\frac{1}{3} \) as \( \frac{1}{3} \), disregarding the negative sign entirely. This omission caused them to compute the reciprocal of the absolute value alone, yielding \( 3 \), but they incorrectly wrote \( \frac{1}{3} \) instead. The misconception aligns with ignoring the negative sign during reciprocal computation, not with misplacing it in the result. Related misconceptions like applying the negative post-reciprocal or declaring negatives undefined do not match, as the student preserved neither the sign nor the magnitude correctly.
